section-block.rac_book_title_byline: by Rose Ann Tahe and Nancy Bo Flood, illustrated by Jonathan Nelson
section-block.rac_book_summary: In Navajo families, a baby’s first laugh is very important. Who will make the baby laugh first?

section-block.rac_copyright_line: 978-1-338-64272-8. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. First Laugh—Welcome, Baby! by Rose Ann Tahe and Nancy Bo Flood, illustrated by Jonathan Nelson. Text copyright © 2018 by Nancy Bo Flood and Rose Ann Tahe. Illustrations copyright © 2018 by Jonathan Nelson. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Charlesbridge Publishing, Inc. Clifford the Big Red DogTM illustration copyright © The Norman Bridwell Trust.

section-block.rac_body-text: Talk to children about families. Ask them to name different members of a family (father, mother, son, daughter, grandparents, etc.).
Invite children to sing a song to the tune “Frere Jacques.” “I love Mommy,” (repeat) “Yes I do,” (repeat) My Mommy loves me, too” (repeat), “Yes, she does.” (repeat)

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read First Laugh—Welcome, Baby! by Rose Ann Tahe and Nancy Bo Flood and illustrated by Jonathan Nelson.
Scout loves reading about families. He’s very excited to read this narrative. He wants to learn about the special traditions of this Navajo family.

section.rac_guiding-question_blue: There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we finish the book. Ready?
What different family members do you hear about in the story?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What is the family waiting for the baby to do for the first time?
What does Papa do all week long? Where does Mama work?
Who is cooking for the family?
Navajo families carry babies around on a cradle board. This baby is snug on his cradle board. Can you think of any other ways that babies can be snug?
The baby rides a horse with his grandmother. What does the grandmother do to make the baby grin?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What different family members do you hear about in the story?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, pick 2–3 children with Equity Sticks to share.
Possible responses:
Write and read aloud short sentences about families as children watch and listen.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Is the story about a family or friends?
The story is about a f_________ (family).
The story is about a family.
Describe one of the family members in the story.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Young children need plenty of opportunities to practice social and emotional skills in the classroom, at play, and at home. This week, while talking about families, you will have opportunities to gauge children’s emotional-social skills as they interact with you and other children. Note which areas related to family life require more awareness.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Use Your Imagination
section-block.rac_body-text: Discuss with children how they can use their imaginations to think about what different families do. What would it be like to be part of the Navajo family in the story waiting for the baby to laugh for the first time? What can you imagine doing to make the baby in the story laugh?

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to revisit the book First Laugh—Welcome, Baby! by Rose Ann Tahe and Nancy Bo Flood and illustrated by Jonathan Nelson. We will think about how we can use our imaginations to understand the story better.
Clifford enjoys reading stories like this one where he can use his imagination.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread the book and talk about how we can use our imaginations to think about families.
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Mama is a teacher. Use your imagination to pretend that you are a teacher just like Mama. What would you teach? (MB)
Big sister is making food for the baby. Can you use your imagination to think about what the food might smell like? (MB)
What does the baby do while his mama weaves a rug?
The baby opens his mouth wide and stretches. What is he doing?
How does the baby’s grandfather try to make the baby smile? Does the baby smile?

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to work in groups to create pretend extended families. Have children choose different family roles they want to be such as parents, grandparents, children, aunts and uncles, cousins, and so on. Have them imagine some traditions that their pretend family follows. For example, in the book, the Navajo family pays a lot of attention to the first time a baby laughs. Have children imagine what kinds of “firsts” other families might celebrate. What special foods would they eat? Who would cook the food? What kinds of activities would the families like to do? Would the family members speak more than one language?
Transcribe children’s speech as they use their imaginations to talk about what different families do.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Developing a healthy imagination is a key motivation and creativity skill that enables children to engage with the world in meaningful ways. As they talk about families this week, encourage children to use their imaginations to creatively problem-solve a range of scenarios (Hermes/healthfully.com, August, 13, 2019).

section-block.rac_body-text: Talk with children about how they can learn about new families by asking a lot of questions.
Place chairs together to simulate a car and have children take turns being the parent driving children to different places. Talk about where they are going as a family and why.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to revisit First Laugh—Welcome, Baby! by Rose Ann Tahe and Nancy Bo Flood and illustrated by Jonathan Nelson.
Scout has lots of questions about the story. He loves to ask questions so he can learn all about this family.

section.rac_guiding-question_blue: This is the guiding question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we finish the book. Ready?
What activities do different family members do with the baby?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 3 prompts. Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to answer questions. Have back-and-forth conversations with children to extend language.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Take a look at the Navajo words for grandmother and papa. Do you use any special names like that at home?
Big sister is in the kitchen making cornmeal mush for the family. Do you eat any special dishes with your family?
Grandmother shows the baby the windmill with the spinning silver blades. What is the windmill used for?
Why is big brother making faces at the baby while sister plays the Navajo flute?
When the baby finally laughs for the first time, sister giggles. Why is the family so happy that the baby laughed?

section.rac_guiding-question_blue: Did you think of questions you wanted to ask as we read the story today? Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
What activities do different family members do with the baby?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, use Equity Sticks to choose 2–3 children to share their thinking.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: The family eats with the baby.
The mama weaves a rug with the baby.
The grandmother rides a horse with the baby.

section.rac_body-text: Have children talk about what they learned about families and help them write a list of key points.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Does the grandmother ride a horse or a train with the baby?
The grandmother rides a h_____ (horse) with the baby.
The grandmother rides a horse with the baby.
What do big brother and sister do with the baby?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Increasingly diverse classrooms work to create a safe, nurturing environment. Sharing books like this week’s read aloud will demonstrate how all children benefit from being exposed to other languages and cultures. Talk about the Navajo words in the story and ask children to share some corresponding words from their home language.

section-block.rac_body-text: Lead children in a discussion of all they have learned about families this week. Talk about how this knowledge might help them in the future.
Bring some playhouses and toy people into the center of your circle. Invite groups of children to act out different things that families do together.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read a poster called My Family and Me. It shows several different family groups.
Scout enjoys looking at posters, especially ones that show families. This poster reminds him of his own family members.
First Laugh—Welcome, Baby! and My Family and Me both look at different family groups. Let’s see if we can find connections between the two.
As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about how it connects to this week’s concept question:

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the poster, then use the following prompts to discuss it.
Use Equity Sticks to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Who can come point to the family reading a book? What else do families do together?
Who can come point to the grandparents, grandchild, and a pet? Whose dog do you think it is?
Who can come point to the picture of the aunt, uncle, and cousins? Do you have any aunts and uncles? Do you get the chance to spend time with them? When?

section.rac_body-text: Have children look through old magazines for pictures of things they like to do with their families. Help children cut out the pictures and glue the pictures onto a large poster board you can call “Things Our Families Like to Do.” Children can draw pictures of their family members in any blank spaces on the poster. Help children to identify patterns in the activities shown on the poster.
Provide a writing prompt about families and give ongoing feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Self-regulation is an important Executive Function that children must master in order to do well in school and in life. Take advantage of opportunities this week to manage children’s expectations and frustrations as they work with this theme. (“How Can We Help Kids with Self-Regulation?”, n.d.)

section-block.rac_body-text: Have children recite a family fingerplay such as “Here is Daddy (thumb), Here is Mommy (index finger), I make three (pinkie finger),” and then using more fingers depending on each child’s family members. Be sensitive to children who have different parenting configurations and those who have very few relatives.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to retell and reenact the book First Laugh—Welcome, Baby! written by Rose Ann Tahe and Nancy Bo Flood and illustrated by Jonathan Nelson.
Scout loves to read this narrative. A narrative means it is a story that the author made up. Some narrative stories are based on real people.
This week we read all about how this family waited for their baby to do something for the first time. As we read the book one more time, I want you to think about this guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How do family members show that they care about each other?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to pick children to actively participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What are the family members doing in the picture on this page that’s the same as in the My Family and Me Big Chart poster?
What is happening in these pictures? Where is the baby going? Have you ever been to a place that looks like this?
What are the parents doing with the baby? Do you think the baby likes it? Do people sometimes sit together like that in your family?
Name some of the things on these pages that tell you how the family members feel about the baby. Why do you think everyone cheers?
“We welcome you, Navajo Baby.” How do these people welcome the baby? Do any of your family events look like this?

section.rac_guiding-question_blue: Invite children to turn and talk about the guiding question:
How do family members show that they care about each other?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, pick 2–3 children with Equity Sticks to share.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Family members spend time with each other.
Family members laugh and play together.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write about their families and share their work.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Do family members spend time together or spend time away?
What special things do you do with your family?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: For preschoolers, reading comes alive when they see how the ideas and themes in a read aloud connect to other books and to their own lives. Make sure other books about families are available to children as they continue to explore this fascinating topic. Use it as a springboard to look at their developing sense of self.
